titles.title: Managing uncertainty in soil carbon feedbacks to climate change

custom_metadata.assertion: The authors declare no competing financial interests.

citation.author: RT Conant
citation.unstructured_citation: Conant, R. T. et al. Temperature and soil organic matter decomposition rates — synthesis of current knowledge and a way forward. Glob. Change Biol. 17, 3392–3404 (2011).

citation.unstructured_citation: Lu, M. et al. Responses of ecosystem carbon cycle to experimental warming: a meta-analysis. Ecology 94, 726–738 (2013).

citation.unstructured_citation: Dorrepaal, E. et al. Carbon respiration from subsurface peat accelerated by climate warming in the subarctic. Nature 460, 616–619 (2013).

citation.unstructured_citation: Frey, S. D., Lee, J., Melillo, J. M. & Six, J. The temperature response of soil microbial efficiency and its feedback to climate. Nature Clim. Change 3, 395–398 (2013).

citation.unstructured_citation: Karhu, K. et al. Temperature sensitivity of soil respiration rates enhanced by microbial community response. Nature 513, 81–84 (2014).

citation.unstructured_citation: Melillo, J. M. et al. Soil warming, carbon–nitrogen interactions, and forest carbon budgets. Proc. Natl Acad. Sci. USA 108, 9508–9512 (2011).

citation.unstructured_citation: Zhou, J. et al. Microbial mediation of carbon-cycle feedbacks to climate warming. Nature Clim. Change 2, 106–110 (2012).

citation.author: P Friedlingstein
citation.unstructured_citation: Friedlingstein, P. et al. Uncertainties in CMIP5 climate projections due to carbon cycle feedbacks. J Clim. 27, 511–526 (2014).

citation.author: VK Arora
citation.unstructured_citation: Arora, V. K. et al. Carbon-concentration and carbon-climate feedbacks in CMIP5 Earth System Models. J Clim. 26, 5289–5314 (2013).

citation.author: C Jones
citation.unstructured_citation: Jones, C. et al. Twenty-first-century compatible CO2 emissions and airborne fraction simulated by CMIP5 Earth system models under four representative concentration pathways. J Clim. 26, 4398–4413 (2013). This study laid out the idea of 'allowable emissions', highlighting the importance of terrestrial carbon cycle uncertainty in projecting allowable greenhouse gas emissions that are compatible with specified climate targets.

citation.author: P Ciais
citation.volume_title: Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis
citation.unstructured_citation: Ciais, P. et al. in Climate Change 2013: The Physical Science Basis (eds Stocker, T. F. et al.) 465–570 (IPCC, Cambridge Univ. Press, 2013).

citation.author: EG Jobbágy
citation.unstructured_citation: Jobbágy, E. G. & Jackson, R. B. The vertical distribution of soil organic carbon and its relation to climate and vegetation. Ecol. Appl. 10, 423–436 (2000).

citation.author: C Tarnocai
citation.unstructured_citation: Tarnocai, C. et al. Soil organic carbon pools in the northern circumpolar permafrost region. Glob. Biogeochem. Cycles 23, GB2023 (2009).

citation.author: KL Denman
citation.volume_title: Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis
citation.unstructured_citation: Denman, K. L. et al. in Climate Change 2007: The Physical Science Basis (eds Solomon, S. et al.) 499–587 (IPCC, Cambridge Univ. Press, 2007).

citation.author: CP Giardina
citation.unstructured_citation: Giardina, C. P., Litton, C. M., Crow, S. E. & Asner, G. P. Warming-related increases in soil CO2 efflux are explained by increased below-ground carbon flux. Nature Clim. Change 4, 822–827 (2014). This study across an elevation gradient in a tropical forest showed that the positive relationship between temperature and soil respiration rates occurred not through expected direct warming effects on soil-C decomposition but because of higher plant C inputs belowground.

citation.author: MWI Schmidt
citation.unstructured_citation: Schmidt, M. W. I. et al. Persistence of soil organic matter as an ecosystem property. Nature 478, 49–56 (2011).

citation.author: DA Davidson
citation.unstructured_citation: Davidson, D. A., Savage, K. E. & Finzi, A. C. A big-microsite framework for soil carbon modeling. Glob. Change Biol. 20, 3610–3620 (2014). This opinion piece proposed a modular model structure to represent the complexity of processes influencing soil C turnover, bringing representations of soil C turnover in line with those of photosynthesis in ecosystem and global models.

citation.author: WR Wieder
citation.unstructured_citation: Wieder, W. R., Grandy, A. S., Kallenbach, C. M. & Bonan, G. B. Integrating microbial physiology and physio-chemical principles in soils with the MIcrobial–MIneral Carbon Stabilization (MIMICS) model. Biogeosci. 11, 1147–1185 (2014).

citation.author: WR Wieder
citation.unstructured_citation: Wieder, W. R., Bonan, G. B. & Allison, S. D. Global soil carbon projections are improved by modelling microbial processes. Nature Clim. Change 3, 909–912 (2013).

citation.author: DS Jenkinson
citation.unstructured_citation: Jenkinson, D. S., Adams, D. E. & Wild, A. Model estimates of CO2 emissions from soil in response to global warming. Nature 351, 304–306 (1991).

citation.author: KEO Todd-Brown
citation.unstructured_citation: Todd-Brown, K. E. O., Hopkins, F. M., Kivlin, S. N., Talbot, J. M. & Allison, S. D. A framework for representing microbial decomposition in coupled climate models. Biogeochem. 109, 19–33 (2012).

citation.author: MJ Castellano
citation.unstructured_citation: Castellano, M. J., Mueller, K. E., Olk, D. C., Sawyer, J. E. & Six, J. Integrating plant litter quality, soil organic matter stabilization, and the carbon saturation concept. Glob. Change Biol. 21, 3200–3209 (2015). This opinion laid out a new conceptual model that integrates advances in understanding of how microbial physiology controls soil C cycling, with established physico-chemical principles that dictate whether physiological responses influence soil C stocks.

citation.author: MF Cotrufo
citation.unstructured_citation: Cotrufo, M. F., Wallenstein, M. D., Boot, C. M., Denef, K. & Paul, E. The Microbial Efficiency-Matrix Stabilization (MEMS) framework integrates plant litter decomposition with soil organic matter stabilization: do labile plant inputs form stable soil organic matter? Glob. Change Biol. 19, 988–995 (2013).

citation.author: P Friedlingstein
citation.unstructured_citation: Friedlingstein, P. et al. Climate-carbon cycle feedback analysis: results from the C4MIP model intercomparison. J. Clim. 19, 3337–3353 (2006).

citation.author: PM Cox
citation.unstructured_citation: Cox, P. M. et al. Sensitivity of tropical carbon to climate change constrained by carbon dioxide variability. Nature 494, 341–344 (2013).

citation.author: J-F Exbrayat
citation.unstructured_citation: Exbrayat, J.-F., Pitman, A. J. & Abramowitz, G. Response of microbial decomposition to spin-up explains CMIP5 soil carbon range until 2100. Geosci. Model Dev. 7, 3481–3504 (2014).

citation.author: KEO Todd-Brown
citation.unstructured_citation: Todd-Brown, K. E. O. et al. Causes of variation in soil carbon simulations from CMIP5 Earth system models and comparison with observations. Biogeosci. 10, 1717–1736 (2013).

citation.author: E Hawkins
citation.unstructured_citation: Hawkins, E. & Sutton, R. The potential to narrow uncertainty in regional climate predictions. Bull. Am. Meteorol. Soc. 90, 1095–1107 (2009). This study identified sources of uncertainty in physical climate projections: revealing that at decadal timescales model uncertainty is a dominant uncertainty source at regional and global scales, and highlighting the large gains in certainty possible by refining climate models.

citation.author: R Knutti
citation.unstructured_citation: Knutti, R. & Sedláček, J. Robustness and uncertainties in the new CMIP5 climate model projections. Nature Clim. Change 3, 369–373 (2013). This study showed that model spread (that is, uncertainty) in physical-based climate projections changed little from the fourth to fifth assessment report of the IPCC, yet the authors argued that confidence in these projections should be substantially greater given major advances in representing mechanistic understanding.

citation.author: JM Melillo
citation.unstructured_citation: Melillo, J. M. et al. Soil warming and carbon-cycle feedbacks to the climate system. Science 298, 2173–2176 (2002).

citation.author: MUF Kirschbaum
citation.unstructured_citation: Kirschbaum, M. U. F. The temperature dependence of organic-matter decomposition — still a topic of debate. Soil Biol. Biochem. 38, 2510–2518 (2006).

citation.author: MS Torn
citation.unstructured_citation: Torn, M. S., Vitousek, P. M. & Trumbore, S. E. The influence of nutrient availability on soil organic matter turnover estimated by incubations and radiocarbon modeling. Ecosystems 8, 352–372 (2005).

citation.author: J Lehmann
citation.unstructured_citation: Lehmann, J. et al. Spatial complexity of soil organic matter forms at nanometre scales. Nature Geosci. 1, 238–242 (2008).

citation.author: C Vogel
citation.unstructured_citation: Vogel, C. et al. Submicron structures provide preferential spots for carbon and nitrogen sequestration in soils. Nature Commun. 5, 2947 (2014). This empirical study showed that decomposition of plant C inputs into more stable soil C fractions occurred preferentially via association with mineral surfaces already clustered with organic matter, changing ideas about how soil clay content relates to the potential of soils to sequester C.

citation.author: MS Strickland
citation.unstructured_citation: Strickland, M. S., DeVore, J. L., Maerz, J. C. & Bradford, M. A. Grass invasion of a hardwood forest is associated with declines in belowground carbon pools. Glob. Change Biol. 16, 1338–1350 (2010).

citation.author: MA Bradford
citation.unstructured_citation: Bradford, M. A., Keiser, A. D., Davies, C. A., Mersmann, C. A. & Strickland, M. S. Empirical evidence that soil carbon formation from plant inputs is positively related to microbial growth. Biogeochem. 113, 271–281 (2013).

citation.author: KE Clemmensen
citation.unstructured_citation: Clemmensen, K. E. et al. Roots and associated fungi drive long-term carbon sequestration in boreal forest. Science 339, 1615–1618 (2013).

citation.author: M Keiluweit
citation.unstructured_citation: Keiluweit, M. et al. Mineral protection of soil carbon counteracted by root exudates. Nature Clim. Change 5, 588–595 (2015). This empirical study showed that plant-root inputs could directly liberate soil C from protective associations with minerals, bypassing the presumed direct microbial role in decomposing this 'stable' soil C fraction.

citation.author: C Liang
citation.unstructured_citation: Liang, C. & Balser, T. C. Warming and nitrogen deposition lessen microbial residue contribution to soil carbon pool. Nature Commun. 3, 1222 (2012).

citation.author: JC Neff
citation.unstructured_citation: Neff, J. C. et al. Variable effects of nitrogen additions on the stability and turnover of soil carbon. Nature 419, 915–917 (2002).

citation.author: MS Torn
citation.unstructured_citation: Torn, M. S. et al. A call for international soil experiment networks for studying, predicting, and managing global change impacts. SOIL 1, 575–582 (2015).

citation.author: SA Sistla
citation.unstructured_citation: Sistla, S. A. et al. Long-term warming restructures Arctic tundra without changing net soil carbon storage. Nature 497, 615–618 (2013).

citation.author: RM Gifford
citation.unstructured_citation: Gifford, R. M. & Roderick, M. L. Soil carbon stocks and bulk density: spatial or cumulative mass coordinates as a basis of expression? Glob. Change Biol. 9, 1507–1514 (2003). This study showed how conventional soil sampling procedures might fail to measure real changes in soil C stocks with time, and the authors proposed that a mass-dependent method be broadly adopted to address these issues.

citation.author: DW Hopkins
citation.unstructured_citation: Hopkins, D. W. et al. Soil organic carbon contents in long-term experimental grassland plots in the UK (Palace Leas and Park Grass) have not changed consistently in recent decades. Glob. Change Biol. 15, 1739–1754 (2009).

citation.unstructured_citation: Tang, J. & Riley, W. J. Weaker soil carbon–climate feedbacks resulting from microbial and abiotic interactions. Nature Clim. Change 5, 56–60 (2015). This study showed that use of a dynamic, as opposed to the conventional static, model structure to represent spatiotemporal dependencies in temperature, microbial and mineral surface interactions, predicted weaker but more variable soil-C–climate feedbacks.
